Award.AwardTitle: Shelf-Edge Circulation on the West Antarctic Peninsula from Archived ADCP Data: Follow-on Analyses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decade the USAP ships, RV/AS Gould and RV/IB Palmer, have used hull-mounted acoustic Doppler current profilers (ADCP) to routinely record underway, along track velocity profiles beneath the ships. This has resulted in a growing database of ADCP transects, especially in the region of the West Antarctic Peninsula (WAP). Combined with other hydrographic data (e.g. XBT/ XCTD data, drifter tracks, some limited moorings) this current velocity data will be used for further analysis of the physical circulation in this ecologically and climatically sensitive region of the Southern Ocean. Processes including inter-annual and spatial variability of WAP shelf-edge and cross-shelf transport, the effects of tides, circulation controls upon sea-ice formation and associated Antarctic ecosystems (e.g. krill) are some of the key circulation features that may be more accurately inferred from these combined data sets.

This study will support the development of a graduate student in descriptive physical oceanography, and introduce undergraduate students to quantitative scientific analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Until quite recently, understanding of shelf circulation on the West Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) was derived almost exclusively from hydrographic data, augmented by drifter tracks and a very few current-meter timeseries from moorings.  This project additionally examined WAP shelf-edge and shelf circulation using archived shipboard Acoustic  Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) data from the R/V Nathaniel B. Palmer and R/V Laurence M. Gould. Following a prior project, this work has focused directly on seasonal variation in circulation connecting the Bransfield Strait with surrounding regions to the southwest and northeast. At the southwest, variability occurs in flow through Boyd Strait, south of the westernmost South Shetland Islands, Smith Island, and in the Gerlach Strait between Trinity Island and the West Antarctic Peninsula. The magnitude of outflow in the Bransfield Jet at the northeast is largest in winter, with large inflow apparent in the Jet at the southeast end of the Bransfield Strait and at the northwest end, near the West Antarctic Peninsula. These transports are continuing to be quantified by season, and are being compared to biological fluxes suggested by satellite ocean color imagery for the area (Marrari et al., DSR II, 2008, pp377-392). Results were presented at the 2014 Ocean Sciences meeting, from which a manuscript is in preparation.

The large SO GLOBEC effort in this area is testimony to the importance of understanding circulation here, in order to understand and quantify life-cycles and importance of krill in the Antarctic ecosystem.  Circulation controls not only the connections between sites of krill spawning, recruitment, and high chla content, which presumably correlates to krill food stocks, but also contributes to or controls nutrient and heat budgets for the shelf, thus affecting ecosystems from the building block level up, as well as influencing sea-ice development, and thus both physical habitat and stratification on the shelf. This project specifically addressed connectivity and cross-shelf transport directly relevant to these larger issues, and will guide continuing model development efforts.  Accurately modeling of broad circulation
features and local episodic processes is quite difficult, and depends on validation from observations. 

Two undergraduate interns have contributed o this effort, and both have developed their interests in computer science and data analysis as a result.
